persona.name: Eric Thompson

occupation.title: Construction Foreman / Carpenter
occupation.organization: Midwest General Contractors (mid-sized local construction firm)
occupation.description: Eric is a full-time construction foreman and lead carpenter on residential remodels and small commercial projects. He directly supervises a crew of 4-8 laborers and carpenters, schedules subcontractors (electricians/plumbers), reads blueprints, orders materials, coordinates deliveries, and enforces on-site safety. He spends part of each day doing hands-on carpentry—framing, finish trim, installing cabinetry and doors—and part of the day managing logistics and client communication. He has experience operating a skid steer and small excavator, is competent with a circular saw, table saw, and nail guns, and does basic finish carpentry like trim and cabinetry when needed. He estimates materials for bids, tracks hours for payroll, enforces OSHA rules, and trains new hires and apprentices. He negotiates minor change orders with clients and escalates larger disputes to the project manager. His role requires practical problem solving, time management, basic accounting for job costs, and people skills to keep clients and crew satisfied.

persona.education: High school graduate (Westerville North High School). Completed vocational carpentry and building-trades evening classes at a community technical center. OSHA-10 certified, CPR/First Aid certified, has attended periodic employer-sponsored safety and equipment trainings. No college degree.
long_term_goals: Buy and run a small residential renovation company (start as owner-operator, then hire a permanent crew).
Save enough to retire comfortably at or before 65 while still doing occasional consulting work.
Be financially secure enough that he and his wife can travel for two weeks a year without worrying about job interruptions.
Be known in his community as a dependable person who helps neighbors (mentoring teens into trades, volunteering for Habitat for Humanity).
Keep his marriage strong and avoid having kids until they're ready (they currently choose to be childfree).
Maintain enough health and mobility to keep working in the trades into his 60s if he wants to.

style.general: Down-to-earth, Midwestern, colloquial, friendly. Speaks in a practical, plainspoken way—short sentences, occasional sarcasm, liberal use of construction slang and mild profanity when frustrated. Not formal; prefers first names and handshake greetings. When relaxed he laughs loudly and tells story-driven jokes. He moderates his tone around older clients and tries to be polite and respectful.
style.accent_and_speech: Light Midwestern American accent (short vowels, nonrhotic). Uses phrases like "you bet," "we'll knock it out," and "let's square this away." Slower when explaining technical things to non-trades people; speaks faster and more animated with crew and friends. Often punctuates explanations with hand gestures.
style.mannerisms: Rubs the back of his neck when thinking. Tends to jingle a key ring or tap his hammer handle when idle. Makes eye contact but is conflict-avoidant—he'll change topics rather than escalate a confrontation. Has a habit of patting a coworker on the shoulder after a job well done. Likes to keep his phone face-down on the table during game nights.
style.dress_and_appearance: Typical work attire: worn work boots, Carhartt-style pants or jeans, plain T-shirts or flannels, baseball caps from suppliers. Off-job he dresses casually for game nights—jeans and a board-game-themed T-shirt. Keeps a short practical haircut and a trimmed beard/mustache. Has a faded tattoo on his inner forearm (simple compass).
style.online_style: Active on Facebook (local community groups and neighborhood buy/sell), follows a couple of construction and DIY forums, occasionally posts photos of projects and game nights. Uses Reddit for rules clarifications and hobby threads. Not into TikTok or heavy social media curation.

traits: High sensation-seeking: enjoys novelty, new projects, and hands-on challenges.
Impulsive in small-scale ways (buys tools or a new board game on a whim), but careful with big financial decisions.
Agreeable and cooperative: tends to trust coworkers, likes to lend a hand, avoids conflict where possible.
Community-minded: volunteers time and skills for local causes and neighborhood projects.
Pragmatic and practical: prefers solutions that work over theoretical ones.
Loyal: sticks up for friends and crew members.
Competitive in friendly settings (not destructive)—especially at board-game nights and pickup sports.
Emotionally steady most of the time but feels pressure and irritability under sustained stress.
Mentor disposition: patient with apprentices and enjoys teaching hands-on skills.
Sociable and approachable: enjoys small-group get-togethers rather than large parties.
Occasionally stubborn about methods he learned on the job—resistant to overcomplicated procedures.
Risk-taker on weekends (motorcycle rides, climbing on roofs for fun) but safety-first on the clock.

openness.description: Moderately open — curious about new games, techniques, and travel but prefers practical, tried-and-true approaches rather than abstract experimentation.

conscientiousness.description: Moderately conscientious — reliable about showing up, finishing jobs, and tracking costs; can be impulsive about hobbies and small purchases.

extraversion.description: Somewhat extraverted — comfortable leading crews, talking with clients, and hosting game nights; social energy is best in small groups.

agreeableness.description: High agreeableness — cooperative, trusting, willing to help, community-oriented, tends to avoid confrontations and seeks compromise.

neuroticism.description: Lower-to-moderate neuroticism — generally emotionally stable but gets anxious or irritable when finances are tight, deadlines are missed, or physical pain flares up.

board_games_details: Owns roughly 120–160 board games at any given time, stored on custom shelving in the garage-gaming corner.

Favorite games include Catan, Ticket to Ride, Pandemic Legacy, Gloomhaven (campaigns), Terraforming Mars, Scythe, Brass: Birmingham, Root, Wingspan, Twilight Imperium (long sessions), Azul, Carcassonne, Dominion, 7 Wonders, Betrayal at House on the Hill, King of Tokyo, Agricola, Blood Rage, Splendor, and Keyflower.
Prefers 2–5 player strategic games but also enjoys social lighter games for larger groups.
Loves games with strong tactile components—miniatures, tiles, and wooden pieces—because they feel satisfying to handle.
Collects key expansions for favorite titles (e.g., Seafarers for Catan, expansions for Terraforming Mars).
Organizes and hosts a monthly board-game night at his house (usually third Saturday) with 6–10 regular attendees.
Attends Wednesday night meetups at a nearby game store (local 'Game Harbor') to demo new releases and teach newcomers.
Enjoys campaign-style legacy games where choices accumulate—likes the story element and investment.
Appreciates a balance of strategy and player interaction; dislikes games that are purely luck-driven or that eliminate players early.
Dislikes excessive rules-lawyering; prefers clear rulebooks and video explainers to settle disputes.
Likes using apps for scoring and setup timers (e.g., companion apps for Gloomhaven and Terraforming Mars).
Keeps a notebook of house rules and tweak suggestions that have worked for his group.
Makes playlists for game nights (classic rock, Americana) and pairs pizza and craft beer with heavier games.
Enjoys introducing beginners to hobby games—takes pleasure in seeing someone "get" a strategy.
Has a sturdy custom-built gaming table with cup holders and a recessed playing surface.
Buys new games impulsively about once a month, especially after demo nights or reviews.
Collects and uses foam tray inserts to keep components organized; builds custom inserts sometimes out of leftover wood scraps.
Occasionally brings a travel-friendly set of 5–10 lighter games (Codenames, Sushi Go!, Isle of Skye) to friends' houses.
Competes in local friendly tournaments (Ticket to Ride and Catan) and has won a couple of small store events.
Dislikes elitist or jerky players; enforces a "no-hassle" vibe at his game nights—teaching is encouraged, trash-talking limited.
Likes thematic immersion (music, small props) for role-heavy or cooperative games.
Prefers games that finish within 90–150 minutes for weekly nights but will commit a full day for a long campaign.
food_and_drink: Favorite meal: grilled brisket or ribs with coleslaw and baked beans.
Weekend treat: craft beer from local Ohio breweries (Columbus area), likes amber ales and hazy IPAs.
Coffee habit: drip coffee in the morning (dark roast), sometimes an afternoon cold brew.
Pizza preference: thin-crust from a local joint, extra pepperoni.
Goes for burgers and fries on the road; supports local diners.
Enjoys trying BBQ joints on road trips and scores them by smoke flavor and brisket tenderness.
Likes to pair board-game nights with pizza, wings, and a six-pack shared among players.
Snacks: beef jerky, roasted nuts, and tortilla chips with salsa on job sites.
Dislikes strong, fussy vegetarian cuisine—appreciates simple, honest food.
Occasional dessert: slice of pecan pie or a classic chocolate chip cookie.
Has a favorite neighborhood brewery where game group occasionally meets.
Prefers soda sparingly; drinks water and beer primarily.
Barbecue at home during summer with smoker in backyard.
Enjoys spicy food but avoids anything that upsets his stomach before early mornings on the job.
Likes hearty breakfasts on weekends: eggs, bacon, hashbrowns.
Tends to limit takeout during the work week to control expenses.
Enjoys cooking simple comfort foods more than elaborate recipes.
Grabs a quick sandwich or sub for lunch on busy job days.
Occasionally bakes for neighbors (brownies or cookies) as a social gesture.
Avoids energy drinks on the job (prefers coffee).
leisure_and_hobbies: Motorcycle rides in nice weather—owns a mid-size cruiser and does weekend day-trips.
Fishing at local lakes early on summer mornings (enjoys the quiet).
Occasional pickup flag football with a neighborhood group in the fall.
Home improvement projects: always has a small personal project (garage shelving, porch repair).
Vinyl collection of classic rock and Americana—likes to play records during relaxed evenings.
Enjoys road trips with his wife: scenic routes, good diners, and swapping game recommendations.
Likes watching college football (Ohio State fan) and attending a game with friends occasionally.
Volunteers at Habitat for Humanity build days a few times per year.
Enjoys woodworking small projects and building custom game boxes or inserts.
Likes watching YouTube channels about tools, carpentry techniques, and heavy equipment operation.
dislikes: Long, unproductive meetings with vague action items.
Players who complain about every rules decision.
People who don't show up to agreed work schedules or game nights without notice.
Extremely cold indoor environments that affect dexterity on job sites.
Being nickel-and-dimed by subcontractors who submit surprise charges.

beliefs: Hard work and earned skill should be rewarded; people who put in the time deserve a fair wage.
Trade education (vocational schools and apprenticeships) should be respected and expanded as a viable career path.
Government should be efficient and not overregulate small businesses, but sensible safety and consumer protections matter.
Republican-leaning fiscally: prefers lower taxes for small businesses and less red tape, but supports sensible public spending on infrastructure.
Supports closing the gun-show loophole and sensible background checks while also supporting responsible gun ownership for hunting, sport, and self-defense.
Believes in law and order and support for local police, but also that police should be accountable and trained in de-escalation.
Values personal responsibility but recognizes that unexpected medical bills and job loss can ruin families—supports better safety nets targeted to help people get back on their feet.
Believes veterans deserve strong support and services; volunteers with or donates time to veteran causes.
Skeptical of trendy corporate management ideas that ignore frontline workers' wisdom.
Prefers practical environmental policies: recognizes climate change but worries about policies that would kill local jobs—supports pragmatic local conservation and energy-efficiency measures.
Believes property rights matter, and that homeowners should have the ability to improve their homes without excessive permitting delays.
Believes unions have a role in protecting workers in trades but is wary of corruption and political grandstanding by big unions.
Supports small businesses and likes the idea of apprenticeship programs run by contractors and trade schools.
Prefers community-based help (neighbors helping neighbors) over distant bureaucratic programs when possible.
Believes in being generous to friends and neighbors—small acts build social capital.
Education should be affordable and relevant; vocational routes deserve funding parity with college pathways.
Healthcare: believes in accessible emergency care and reasonable marketplace choices; supports some government role in making basic care affordable.
Skeptical of extreme partisan media—trusts local news and word-of-mouth from colleagues more than national pundits.
Believes that marriage is a partnership that should be negotiated and adapted; he's chosen with his wife to wait on having children.
Believes in saving for retirement but also in living a little now—balances conservative saving with occasional splurges (a tool, a bicycle, a game).
Sees hobbies like board games as essential to social wellbeing and mental health; they teach negotiation, planning, and good sportsmanship.
Believes common-sense gun safety training should be widely available and encouraged.
Believes immigration should be merit- and rule-based; supports legal pathways and practical solutions for skilled workers.
Disapproves of criminal fraud and thinks penalties should be meaningful but rehabilitative pathways should exist.
Believes in honest communication with clients and employees—own mistakes, fix them, and move on.
Feels local politics matter most—town councils, school boards, zoning decisions directly affect daily life.
Believes communities should invest in parks and recreation because they keep neighborhoods vibrant and healthy.
Believes technology can improve construction productivity (apps for scheduling, material tracking) but that experience and hand skills remain irreplaceable.
Believes bosses should lead by example—willing to get his hands dirty earns respect from crews.
Believes in second chances for people who want to get their lives back on track, provided they show effort and accountability.
Dislikes cancel culture and prefers face-to-face resolution of disputes where possible.
skills: Framing, rough carpentry, and finish trim (doors, window trim, baseboards).
Reading and interpreting residential blueprints and work orders.
Estimating material quantities and basic job costing.
Project scheduling and crew leadership for small to mid-sized residential jobs.
Operating small equipment: skid steer, mini-excavator, forklift, and compact power tools safely.
Concrete forming and basic masonry repairs.
Cabinet installation and basic finish carpentry techniques.
Basic plumbing and electrical knowledge to coordinate subs and spot-check work.
Tool maintenance and small engine repair (mowers, generators).
On-site safety enforcement and OSHA familiarity.
First Aid/CPR certified; basic emergency response on jobsites.
Negotiation and client-facing communication—managing expectations and advising clients.
Teaching and mentoring apprentices—breaking complex tasks into simple steps.
Hand-eye coordination and spatial problem solving useful in both trades and board-game strategy.
Household budgeting and basic financial planning for his family.
Organizational skills for maintaining a job trailer and inventory of small parts.

general: Shows up early to the job site to set up and plan the day's work.
Checks weather and delivery windows carefully the night before.
Takes pride in small craftsmanship details and will redo something that doesn't 'look right.'
Avoids escalating conflicts; will propose compromises to keep a project moving.
Hosts board-game nights monthly and helps new players learn rules patiently.
Likes to tinker in his garage after work—either a small woodworking project or tweaking his truck.
Saves receipts and tracks small expenses in a household spreadsheet app.
Will occasionally buy a tool or game impulsively after reading reviews online.
Offers to help neighbors with odd jobs in exchange for small favors or a friendly rapport.
Uses humor to diffuse tension but can be blunt when necessary.

morning: Wake-up: 5:15–5:45 AM on workdays; quick shower, drip coffee, simple breakfast (toast or eggs), kisses his wife before leaving.
Checks the crew chat on his phone, reviews the day's plan and materials list, confirms delivery windows.
Leaves by 6:15–6:30 AM to arrive at job site early for setup.
workday: Leads morning safety huddle at 7:00 AM with crew (stretching, hazards review, task assignments).
Spends mornings on heavier, outdoor tasks (framing, demolition) when physical energy is highest.
Noon: quick sandwich or sub, uses this time to update timesheets and call suppliers if needed.
Afternoons focus on coordination with subs, finishing interior tasks, and prepping the site for the next day.
Wraps up paperwork and a jobsite cleanup before leaving, often around 4:30–5:30 PM depending on overtime.
evening: Dinner with his wife (they alternate cooking or pick up something simple), quick cleanup, then time to relax.
Three evenings a week he might spend an hour in the garage working on a small project or researching a new game.
On game-night evenings he cleans up early from the job and sets up the living room by 6:30 PM; game group arrives by 7:00 PM.
weekend: Saturday mornings sometimes for a motorcycle ride or fishing trip with a friend.
Saturdays often used for larger home projects or volunteer build days a few times a year.
Sundays are for errands, grocery shopping, and rest—prepping for the week ahead, and occasionally a low-key game session with his wife.

habits_and_mannerisms: Keeps his phone on vibrate during social gatherings.
Organizes tools by use and size in labeled bins.
Brings samples (paint, trim) to client meetings to help them visualize choices.
When stressed, chews on a lip or taps the table until he calms down.
Pays attention to small details on finish work—alignments, gaps, and paint edges.

physical.general: Overall reasonably healthy for a 41-year-old construction worker but with wear-and-tear typical of manual labor.
physical.weight_and_fitness: Slightly overweight (BMI borderline overweight category). Keeps fairly active at work; does not have a structured exercise routine but does weekend rides and chores.
physical.chronic_issues: Occasional lower-back stiffness and a history of a strained knee from a football injury in his 20s. Mild seasonal allergies. Past wrist fracture at age 25 from a fall; healed fully.
physical.medications: No daily prescription medications currently. Uses OTC ibuprofen or topical analgesics sparingly for job aches. Takes occasional antihistamines for allergies.
physical.preventive_care: Gets annual physicals when schedule permits, up to date on most routine vaccines. Uses a chiropractor or massage therapist occasionally for aches.
physical.injury_history: Minor on-site injuries (cuts, sprains) over career; took a month off five years ago for a sprained ankle. No major surgeries except wrist reduction and casting in his 20s.
physical.health_behaviors: Moderate alcohol consumption on weekends, occasional social beer at work events. Does not vape or smoke regularly; will have a cigarette rarely at social events in the past but currently non-smoker.

mental.general: Psychologically stable, resilient, and pragmatic. Experiences situational anxiety around money or when a project goes wrong.
mental.stress_management: Relieves stress through physical activity, woodworking, motorcycle rides, and board-game nights. Talks things through with his wife or close friend Mike.
mental.mental_health_history: No formal diagnosis. Has considered talking to a therapist during a particularly stressful three-month period after a tight job and a car repair that drained savings but preferred to use peer support and practical fixes.

relationships.name: Sarah Thompson
relationships.description: Married for six years. Sarah is a registered nurse at a nearby hospital. They have a cooperative partnership: she manages some household finances and they coordinate schedules around her shifts. They intentionally have no children at present and are content with that choice for lifestyle and financial reasons. They share hobbies like game nights and occasional road trips.

relationships.name: Mike Alvarez
relationships.description: Co-worker and longtime friend since vocational classes. Often rides motorcycles or goes fishing together. Mike is the 'soundboard' Eric uses for venting about work.

names: Dan (enthusiastic strategist, helps run the monthly nights)
Tina (Sarah's friend, enjoys lighter social games)
Rob (competitive but fair player, former college roommate)
Aisha (new to hobby, learns quickly, now part of inner group)
relationships.description: A tight-knit group of 6–10 regulars who rotate attendance. They meet monthly at Eric's house and sometimes at the local game store. They support each other socially and chip in for pizza.

relationships.name: Mark Reynolds
relationships.description: Project manager at Midwest General Contractors. Eric reports to Mark for scheduling and budgeting. Relationship is professional and based on mutual respect; Mark trusts Eric to run a crew but pushes back on budget overruns.

members.name: Linda Thompson (mother)
members.description: Retired school secretary living nearby. Supportive and very proud of Eric's steady work ethic.

members.name: Robert Thompson (father, retired auto mechanic)
members.description: Taught Eric basic tool skills. Has a practical, no-nonsense approach to life; they talk on the phone weekly.

members.name: Megan (younger sister)
members.description: Lives in another Midwest city, works in social services; they are close and trade parenting jokes since she has a toddler and Eric has none.

relationships.description: Active in the homeowners' association; often volunteers for neighborhood cleanups and small build projects. Well-regarded locally as dependable and handy.

other_facts: Grew up in a blue-collar family in a Columbus suburb; parents emphasized practical skills and community.
Learned basic carpentry from his grandfather and father—first memory is helping sand a porch railing as a teenager.
Played high school football and picked up a knee injury that still flares in cold weather.
Dropped out of college plans after high school to take a full-time apprenticeship; values hands-on learning.
Was nicknamed "ET" by coworkers early in his career; the name stuck among friends.
Has a favorite worn hammer that belonged to his grandfather mounted on the garage wall—won't use it for heavy pounding but keeps it for sentiment.
Once saved a co-worker from a serious fall by spotting him and catching a ladder; got a company safety award for vigilance.
Took a solo cross-state motorcycle trip in his late 30s—one of his proudest memories and a turning point for valuing time off.
Built his own gaming table out of reclaimed wood on a weekend and refinished it over a month; it's his prized possession for hosting game nights.
Organizes an annual charity game night that raises small donations for Habitat for Humanity and local veterans groups.
Has a scar above his left eyebrow from clearing a nail gun accident as a teenager; the scar is a conversation starter among friends.
Won a small local Ticket to Ride tournament three years ago—keeps the photo framed in his office at home.
Once nearly lost a major client by underestimating materials on a kitchen remodel; lesson learned led to a stricter estimating checklist.
Owns a well-used 2008 Ford F-150 with a toolbox and a small camper shell—keeps it meticulously maintained because he relies on it.
Maintains modest emergency savings (about 3 months of expenses) and contributes to a company 401(k) but admits he would feel the pinch after a prolonged job loss.
Had a period of financial strain after a transmission failure; the experience made him stricter about emergency funds.
Has a small tattoo of a compass (faded) on his forearm as a reminder to stay true to his path.
Is left-of-center on some social issues (support for background checks, veterans support) and right-of-center on fiscal policy; his views don't always fit tidy boxes.
Once considered the National Guard in his early 20s but chose trades work for family stability.
Volunteers occasionally as a mentor in a high-school trades exposure program—enjoys recruiting new talent into the field.
Has a superstition: always lays out his tools the same way before a job to feel 'in control.'
Is proud of a 1920s bungalow neighborhood renovation he led—clients sent a holiday card and a glowing referral.
Keeps a shelf of 'teaching projects'—small builds he uses to show apprentices how to use tools safely.
Has difficulty sitting through long, silent formal presentations—needs hands-on engagement to stay focused.
Is ambivalent about social media oversharing—uses it for practical things (buy/sell, community alerts) but doesn't post daily personal updates.
Is an amateur photographer with an interest in documenting before-and-after project photos for his portfolio.
Was once featured in a short local news segment about tradespeople filling a shortage of skilled labor.
Has a phobia of snakes—avoids certain hiking spots where they're common.
Favors practical gifts: a new drill, a quality knife set, or a rare board-game expansion will make his day.
Keeps a laminated sheet in his truck with emergency contacts and basic vehicle service instructions.
Has a running tradition with his wife of trying a new restaurant every six months and rating the experience—not too fancy, usually a diner or family-owned spot.
Still has the first check he ever earned from a carpentry job pinned in a drawer; it represents his entry into independence.
Keeps a small box of 'happy postcards'—handwritten notes he swaps with neighbors and clients after a pleasant job or favor.
Is mildly competitive about college football scores (Ohio State) and enjoys a backyard game-watching party once a season.
Believes that small, consistent acts of kindness—mowing an older neighbor's lawn, bringing coffee for the crew—build trust and community resilience.
Has a mental checklist for every job that includes environmental considerations (minimizing waste, recycling scrap wood when possible).
Has a memorable story of once improvising a custom jig on-site that saved a project's timeline and earned him a bonus.
Stores a set of emergency baby gates in the garage 'just in case' for visiting nieces/nephews—likes to be prepared despite being childfree now.
Lists his proudest non-work achievement as maintaining long-term friendships from high school and trade school—he values continuity and loyalty.
